column2: Priscian goes yonder with that wretched crowd, And Francis of Accorso; and thou hadst seen there If thou hadst had a hankering for such scurf,
column3: Priscian goes yonder with that wretched crowd, And Francis of Accorso; and thou hadst seen there If thou hadst had a hankering for such scurf,

column2: That one, who by the Servant of the Servants From Arno was transferred to Bacchiglione, Where he has left his sin-excited nerves.
column3: That one, who by the Servant of the Servants From Arno was transferred to Bacchiglione, Where he has left his sin excited nerves.

column2: More would I say, but coming and discoursing Can be no longer; for that I behold New smoke uprising yonder from the sand.
column3: More would I say, but coming and discoursing Can be no longer; for that I behold New smoke uprising yonder from the sand.

column2: A people comes with whom I may not be; Commended unto thee be my Tesoro, In which I still live, and no more I ask."
column3: A people comes with whom I may not be; Commended unto thee be my Tesoro, In which I still live, and no more I ask."

column2: Then he turned round, and seemed to be of those Who at Verona run for the Green Mantle Across the plain; and seemed to be among them
column3: Then he turned round, and seemed to be of those Who at Verona run for the Green Mantle Across the plain; and seemed to be among them

column2: The one who wins, and not the one who loses.
column3: The one who wins, and not the one who loses.

column2: Inferno: Canto XVI
column3: Inferno: Canto sixteen

column2: Now was I where was heard the reverberation Of water falling into the next round, Like to that humming which the beehives make,
column3: Now was I where was heard the reverberation Of water falling into the next round, Like to that humming which the beehives make,

column2: When shadows three together started forth, Running, from out a company that passed Beneath the rain of the sharp martyrdom.
column3: When shadows three together started forth, Running, from out a company that passed Beneath the rain of the sharp martyrdom.

column2: Towards us came they, and each one cried out: "Stop, thou; for by thy garb to us thou seemest To be some one of our depraved city."
column3: Towards us came they, and each one cried out: "Stop, thou; for by thy garb to us thou seemest To be some one of our depraved city."

column2: Ah me! what wounds I saw upon their limbs, Recent and ancient by the flames burnt in! It pains me still but to remember it.
column3: Ah me! what wounds I saw upon their limbs, Recent and ancient by the flames burnt in! It pains me still but to remember it.

column2: Unto their cries my Teacher paused attentive; He turned his face towards me, and "Now wait," He said; "to these we should be courteous.
column3: Unto their cries my Teacher paused attentive; He turned his face towards me, and "Now wait," He said; "to these we should be courteous.

column2: And if it were not for the fire that darts The nature of this region, I should say That haste were more becoming thee than them."
column3: And if it were not for the fire that darts The nature of this region, I should say That haste were more becoming thee than them."

column2: As soon as we stood still, they recommenced The old refrain, and when they overtook us, Formed of themselves a wheel, all three of them.
column3: As soon as we stood still, they recommenced The old refrain, and when they overtook us, Formed of themselves a wheel, all three of them.

column2: As champions stripped and oiled are wont to do, Watching for their advantage and their hold, Before they come to blows and thrusts between them,
column3: As champions stripped and oiled are wont to do, Watching for their advantage and their hold, Before they come to blows and thrusts between them,

column2: Thus, wheeling round, did every one his visage Direct to me, so that in opposite wise His neck and feet continual journey made.
column3: Thus, wheeling round, did every one his visage Direct to me, so that in opposite wise His neck and feet continual journey made.

column2: And, "If the misery of this soft place Bring in disdain ourselves and our entreaties," Began one, "and our aspect black and blistered,
column3: And, "If the misery of this soft place Bring in disdain ourselves and our entreaties," Began one, "and our aspect black and blistered,

column2: Let the renown of us thy mind incline To tell us who thou art, who thus securely Thy living feet dost move along through Hell.
column3: Let the renown of us thy mind incline To tell us who thou art, who thus securely Thy living feet dost move along through Hell.

column2: He in whose footprints thou dost see me treading, Naked and skinless though he now may go, Was of a greater rank than thou dost think;
column3: He in whose footprints thou dost see me treading, Naked and skinless though he now may go, Was of a greater rank than thou dost think;

column2: He was the grandson of the good Gualdrada; His name was Guidoguerra, and in life Much did he with his wisdom and his sword.
column3: He was the grandson of the good Gualdrada; His name was Guidoguerra, and in life Much did he with his wisdom and his sword.

column2: The other, who close by me treads the sand, Tegghiaio Aldobrandi is, whose fame Above there in the world should welcome be.
column3: The other, who close by me treads the sand, Tegghiaio Aldobrandi is, whose fame Above there in the world should welcome be.

column2: And I, who with them on the cross am placed, Jacopo Rusticucci was; and truly My savage wife, more than aught else, doth harm me."
column3: And I, who with them on the cross am placed, Jacopo Rusticucci was; and truly My savage wife, more than aught else, doth harm me."

column2: Could I have been protected from the fire, Below I should have thrown myself among them, And think the Teacher would have suffered it;
column3: Could I have been protected from the fire, Below I should have thrown myself among them, And think the Teacher would have suffered it;

column2: But as I should have burned and baked myself, My terror overmastered my good will, Which made me greedy of embracing them.
column3: But as I should have burned and baked myself, My terror overmastered my good will, Which made me greedy of embracing them.

column2: Then I began: "Sorrow and not disdain Did your condition fix within me so, That tardily it wholly is stripped off,
column3: Then I began: "Sorrow and not disdain Did your condition fix within me so, That tardily it wholly is stripped off,

column2: As soon as this my Lord said unto me Words, on account of which I thought within me That people such as you are were approaching.
column3: As soon as this my Lord said unto me Words, on account of which I thought within me That people such as you are were approaching.

column2: I of your city am; and evermore Your labours and your honourable names I with affection have retraced and heard.
column3: I of your city am; and evermore Your labours and your honourable names I with affection have retraced and heard.

column2: I leave the gall, and go for the sweet fruits Promised to me by the veracious Leader; But to the centre first I needs must plunge."
column3: I leave the gall, and go for the sweet fruits Promised to me by the veracious Leader; But to the centre first I needs must plunge."

column2: So may the soul for a long while conduct Those limbs of thine, did he make answer then, "And so may thy renown shine after thee,
column3: So may the soul for a long while conduct Those limbs of thine, did he make answer then, "And so may thy renown shine after thee,

column2: Valour and courtesy, say if they dwell Within our city, as they used to do, Or if they wholly have gone out of it;
column3: Valour and courtesy, say if they dwell Within our city, as they used to do, Or if they wholly have gone out of it;

column2: For Guglielmo Borsier, who is in torment With us of late, and goes there with his comrades, Doth greatly mortify us with his words."
column3: For Guglielmo Borsier, who is in torment With us of late, and goes there with his comrades, Doth greatly mortify us with his words."

column2: The new inhabitants and the sudden gains, Pride and extravagance have in thee engendered, Florence, so that thou weep'st thereat already!
column3: The new inhabitants and the sudden gains, Pride and extravagance have in thee engendered, Florence, so that thou weep'st thereat already!

column2: In this wise I exclaimed with face uplifted; And the three, taking that for my reply, Looked at each other, as one looks at truth.
column3: In this wise I exclaimed with face uplifted; And the three, taking that for my reply, Looked at each other, as one looks at truth.

column2: If other times so little it doth cost thee, Replied they all, "to satisfy another, Happy art thou, thus speaking at thy will!
column3: If other times so little it doth cost thee, Replied they all, "to satisfy another, Happy art thou, thus speaking at thy will!

column2: Therefore, if thou escape from these dark places, And come to rebehold the beauteous stars, When it shall pleasure thee to say, 'I was,'
column3: Therefore, if thou escape from these dark places, And come to rebehold the beauteous stars, When it shall pleasure thee to say, 'I was,'

column2: See that thou speak of us unto the people." Then they broke up the wheel, and in their flight It seemed as if their agile legs were wings.
column3: See that thou speak of us unto the people." Then they broke up the wheel, and in their flight It seemed as if their agile legs were wings.

column2: Not an Amen could possibly be said So rapidly as they had disappeared; Wherefore the Master deemed best to depart.
column3: Not an Amen could possibly be said So rapidly as they had disappeared; Wherefore the Master deemed best to depart.

column2: I followed him, and little had we gone, Before the sound of water was so near us, That speaking we should hardly have been heard.
column3: I followed him, and little had we gone, Before the sound of water was so near us, That speaking we should hardly have been heard.

column2: Even as that stream which holdeth its own course The first from Monte Veso tow'rds the East, Upon the left-hand slope of Apennine,
column3: Even as that stream which holdeth its own course The first from Monte Veso tow'rds the East, Upon the left hand slope of Apennine,

column2: Which is above called Acquacheta, ere It down descendeth into its low bed, And at Forli is vacant of that name,
column3: Which is above called Acquacheta, ere It down descendeth into its low bed, And at Forli is vacant of that name,

column2: Reverberates there above San Benedetto From Alps, by falling at a single leap, Where for a thousand there were room enough;
column3: Reverberates there above San Benedetto From Alps, by falling at a single leap, Where for a thousand there were room enough;

column2: Thus downward from a bank precipitate, We found resounding that dark-tinted water, So that it soon the ear would have offended.
column3: Thus downward from a bank precipitate, We found resounding that dark tinted water, So that it soon the ear would have offended.

column2: I had a cord around about me girt, And therewithal I whilom had designed To take the panther with the painted skin.
column3: I had a cord around about me girt, And therewithal I whilom had designed To take the panther with the painted skin.

column2: After I this had all from me unloosed, As my Conductor had commanded me, I reached it to him, gathered up and coiled,
column3: After I this had all from me unloosed, As my Conductor had commanded me, I reached it to him, gathered up and coiled,

column2: Whereat he turned himself to the right side, And at a little distance from the verge, He cast it down into that deep abyss.
column3: Whereat he turned himself to the right side, And at a little distance from the verge, He cast it down into that deep abyss.

column2: It must needs be some novelty respond, I said within myself, "to the new signal The Master with his eye is following so."
column3: It must needs be some novelty respond, I said within myself, "to the new signal The Master with his eye is following so."

column2: Ah me! how very cautious men should be With those who not alone behold the act, But with their wisdom look into the thoughts!
column3: Ah me! how very cautious men should be With those who not alone behold the act, But with their wisdom look into the thoughts!

column2: He said to me: "Soon there will upward come What I await; and what thy thought is dreaming Must soon reveal itself unto thy sight."
column3: He said to me: "Soon there will upward come What I await; and what thy thought is dreaming Must soon reveal itself unto thy sight."

column2: Aye to that truth which has the face of falsehood, A man should close his lips as far as may be, Because without his fault it causes shame;
column3: Aye to that truth which has the face of falsehood, A man should close his lips as far as may be, Because without his fault it causes shame;

column2: But here I cannot; and, Reader, by the notes Of this my Comedy to thee I swear, So may they not be void of lasting favour,
column3: But here I cannot; and, Reader, by the notes Of this my Comedy to thee I swear, So may they not be void of lasting favour,

column2: Athwart that dense and darksome atmosphere I saw a figure swimming upward come, Marvellous unto every steadfast heart,
column3: Athwart that dense and darksome atmosphere I saw a figure swimming upward come, Marvellous unto every steadfast heart,

column2: Even as he returns who goeth down Sometimes to clear an anchor, which has grappled Reef, or aught else that in the sea is hidden,
column3: Even as he returns who goeth down Sometimes to clear an anchor, which has grappled Reef, or aught else that in the sea is hidden,

column2: Who upward stretches, and draws in his feet.
column3: Who upward stretches, and draws in his feet.

column2: Inferno: Canto XVII
column3: Inferno: Canto seventeen

column2: Behold the monster with the pointed tail, Who cleaves the hills, and breaketh walls and weapons, Behold him who infecteth all the world.
column3: Behold the monster with the pointed tail, Who cleaves the hills, and breaketh walls and weapons, Behold him who infecteth all the world.

column2: Thus unto me my Guide began to say, And beckoned him that he should come to shore, Near to the confine of the trodden marble;
column3: Thus unto me my Guide began to say, And beckoned him that he should come to shore, Near to the confine of the trodden marble;

column2: And that uncleanly image of deceit Came up and thrust ashore its head and bust, But on the border did not drag its tail.
column3: And that uncleanly image of deceit Came up and thrust ashore its head and bust, But on the border did not drag its tail.

column2: The face was as the face of a just man, Its semblance outwardly was so benign, And of a serpent all the trunk beside.
column3: The face was as the face of a just man, Its semblance outwardly was so benign, And of a serpent all the trunk beside.

column2: Two paws it had, hairy unto the armpits; The back, and breast, and both the sides it had Depicted o'er with nooses and with shields.
column3: Two paws it had, hairy unto the armpits; The back, and breast, and both the sides it had Depicted o'er with nooses and with shields.

column2: With colours more, groundwork or broidery Never in cloth did Tartars make nor Turks, Nor were such tissues by Arachne laid.
column3: With colours more, groundwork or broidery Never in cloth did Tartars make nor Turks, Nor were such tissues by Arachne laid.

column2: As sometimes wherries lie upon the shore, That part are in the water, part on land; And as among the guzzling Germans there,
column3: As sometimes wherries lie upon the shore, That part are in the water, part on land; And as among the guzzling Germans there,

column2: The beaver plants himself to wage his war; So that vile monster lay upon the border, Which is of stone, and shutteth in the sand.
column3: The beaver plants himself to wage his war; So that vile monster lay upon the border, Which is of stone, and shutteth in the sand.

column2: His tail was wholly quivering in the void, Contorting upwards the envenomed fork, That in the guise of scorpion armed its point.
column3: His tail was wholly quivering in the void, Contorting upwards the envenomed fork, That in the guise of scorpion armed its point.

column2: The Guide said: "Now perforce must turn aside Our way a little, even to that beast Malevolent, that yonder coucheth him."
column3: The Guide said: "Now perforce must turn aside Our way a little, even to that beast Malevolent, that yonder coucheth him."

column2: We therefore on the right side descended, And made ten steps upon the outer verge, Completely to avoid the sand and flame;
column3: We therefore on the right side descended, And made ten steps upon the outer verge, Completely to avoid the sand and flame;

column2: And after we are come to him, I see A little farther off upon the sand A people sitting near the hollow place.
column3: And after we are come to him, I see A little farther off upon the sand A people sitting near the hollow place.

column2: Then said to me the Master: "So that full Experience of this round thou bear away, Now go and see what their condition is.
column3: Then said to me the Master: "So that full Experience of this round thou bear away, Now go and see what their condition is.

column2: There let thy conversation be concise; Till thou returnest I will speak with him, That he concede to us his stalwart shoulders."
column3: There let thy conversation be concise; Till thou returnest I will speak with him, That he concede to us his stalwart shoulders."

column2: Thus farther still upon the outermost Head of that seventh circle all alone I went, where sat the melancholy folk.
column3: Thus farther still upon the outermost Head of that seventh circle all alone I went, where sat the melancholy folk.

column2: Out of their eyes was gushing forth their woe; This way, that way, they helped them with their hands Now from the flames and now from the hot soil.
column3: Out of their eyes was gushing forth their woe; This way, that way, they helped them with their hands Now from the flames and now from the hot soil.

column2: Not otherwise in summer do the dogs, Now with the foot, now with the muzzle, when By fleas, or flies, or gadflies, they are bitten.
column3: Not otherwise in summer do the dogs, Now with the foot, now with the muzzle, when By fleas, or flies, or gadflies, they are bitten.

column2: When I had turned mine eyes upon the faces Of some, on whom the dolorous fire is falling, Not one of them I knew; but I perceived
column3: When I had turned mine eyes upon the faces Of some, on whom the dolorous fire is falling, Not one of them I knew; but I perceived

column2: That from the neck of each there hung a pouch, Which certain colour had, and certain blazon; And thereupon it seems their eyes are feeding.
column3: That from the neck of each there hung a pouch, Which certain colour had, and certain blazon; And thereupon it seems their eyes are feeding.

column2: And as I gazing round me come among them, Upon a yellow pouch I azure saw That had the face and posture of a lion.
column3: And as I gazing round me come among them, Upon a yellow pouch I azure saw That had the face and posture of a lion.

column2: Proceeding then the current of my sight, Another of them saw I, red as blood, Display a goose more white than butter is.
column3: Proceeding then the current of my sight, Another of them saw I, red as blood, Display a goose more white than butter is.

column2: And one, who with an azure sow and gravid Emblazoned had his little pouch of white, Said unto me: "What dost thou in this moat?
column3: And one, who with an azure sow and gravid Emblazoned had his little pouch of white, Said unto me: "What dost thou in this moat?

column2: Now get thee gone; and since thou'rt still alive, Know that a neighbour of mine, Vitaliano, Will have his seat here on my left-hand side.
column3: Now get thee gone; and since thou'rt still alive, Know that a neighbour of mine, Vitaliano, Will have his seat here on my left hand side.

column2: A Paduan am I with these Florentines; Full many a time they thunder in mine ears, Exclaiming, 'Come the sovereign cavalier,
column3: A Paduan am I with these Florentines; Full many a time they thunder in mine ears, Exclaiming, 'Come the sovereign cavalier,

column2: He who shall bring the satchel with three goats;'" Then twisted he his mouth, and forth he thrust His tongue, like to an ox that licks its nose.
column3: He who shall bring the satchel with three goats;'" Then twisted he his mouth, and forth he thrust His tongue, like to an ox that licks its nose.

column2: And fearing lest my longer stay might vex Him who had warned me not to tarry long, Backward I turned me from those weary souls.
column3: And fearing lest my longer stay might vex Him who had warned me not to tarry long, Backward I turned me from those weary souls.

column2: I found my Guide, who had already mounted Upon the back of that wild animal, And said to me: "Now be both strong and bold.
column3: I found my Guide, who had already mounted Upon the back of that wild animal, And said to me: "Now be both strong and bold.

column2: Now we descend by stairways such as these; Mount thou in front, for I will be midway, So that the tail may have no power to harm thee."
column3: Now we descend by stairways such as these; Mount thou in front, for I will be midway, So that the tail may have no power to harm thee."

column2: Such as he is who has so near the ague Of quartan that his nails are blue already, And trembles all, but looking at the shade;
column3: Such as he is who has so near the ague Of quartan that his nails are blue already, And trembles all, but looking at the shade;

column2: Even such became I at those proffered words; But shame in me his menaces produced, Which maketh servant strong before good master.
column3: Even such became I at those proffered words; But shame in me his menaces produced, Which maketh servant strong before good master.

column2: I seated me upon those monstrous shoulders; I wished to say, and yet the voice came not As I believed, "Take heed that thou embrace me."
column3: I seated me upon those monstrous shoulders; I wished to say, and yet the voice came not As I believed, "Take heed that thou embrace me."

column2: But he, who other times had rescued me In other peril, soon as I had mounted, Within his arms encircled and sustained me,
column3: But he, who other times had rescued me In other peril, soon as I had mounted, Within his arms encircled and sustained me,

column2: And said: "Now, Geryon, bestir thyself; The circles large, and the descent be little; Think of the novel burden which thou hast."
column3: And said: "Now, Geryon, bestir thyself; The circles large, and the descent be little; Think of the novel burden which thou hast."

column2: Even as the little vessel shoves from shore, Backward, still backward, so he thence withdrew; And when he wholly felt himself afloat,
column3: Even as the little vessel shoves from shore, Backward, still backward, so he thence withdrew; And when he wholly felt himself afloat,

column2: There where his breast had been he turned his tail, And that extended like an eel he moved, And with his paws drew to himself the air.
column3: There where his breast had been he turned his tail, And that extended like an eel he moved, And with his paws drew to himself the air.

column2: A greater fear I do not think there was What time abandoned Phaeton the reins, Whereby the heavens, as still appears, were scorched;
column3: A greater fear I do not think there was What time abandoned Phaeton the reins, Whereby the heavens, as still appears, were scorched;

column2: Nor when the wretched Icarus his flanks Felt stripped of feathers by the melting wax, His father crying, "An ill way thou takest!"
column3: Nor when the wretched Icarus his flanks Felt stripped of feathers by the melting wax, His father crying, "An ill way thou takest!"

column2: Than was my own, when I perceived myself On all sides in the air, and saw extinguished The sight of everything but of the monster.
column3: Than was my own, when I perceived myself On all sides in the air, and saw extinguished The sight of everything but of the monster.

column2: Onward he goeth, swimming slowly, slowly; Wheels and descends, but I perceive it only By wind upon my face and from below.
column3: Onward he goeth, swimming slowly, slowly; Wheels and descends, but I perceive it only By wind upon my face and from below.

column2: I heard already on the right the whirlpool Making a horrible crashing under us; Whence I thrust out my head with eyes cast downward.
column3: I heard already on the right the whirlpool Making a horrible crashing under us; Whence I thrust out my head with eyes cast downward.

column2: Then was I still more fearful of the abyss; Because I fires beheld, and heard laments, Whereat I, trembling, all the closer cling.
column3: Then was I still more fearful of the abyss; Because I fires beheld, and heard laments, Whereat I, trembling, all the closer cling.

column2: I saw then, for before I had not seen it, The turning and descending, by great horrors That were approaching upon divers sides.
column3: I saw then, for before I had not seen it, The turning and descending, by great horrors That were approaching upon divers sides.

column2: As falcon who has long been on the wing, Who, without seeing either lure or bird, Maketh the falconer say, "Ah me, thou stoopest,"
column3: As falcon who has long been on the wing, Who, without seeing either lure or bird, Maketh the falconer say, "Ah me, thou stoopest,"

column2: Descendeth weary, whence he started swiftly, Thorough a hundred circles, and alights Far from his master, sullen and disdainful;
column3: Descendeth weary, whence he started swiftly, Thorough a hundred circles, and alights Far from his master, sullen and disdainful;

column2: Even thus did Geryon place us on the bottom, Close to the bases of the rough-hewn rock, And being disencumbered of our persons,
column3: Even thus did Geryon place us on the bottom, Close to the bases of the rough hewn rock, And being disencumbered of our persons,

column2: He sped away as arrow from the string.
column3: He sped away as arrow from the string.

column2: Inferno: Canto XVIII
column3: Inferno: Canto eighteen

column2: There is a place in Hell called Malebolge, Wholly of stone and of an iron colour, As is the circle that around it turns.
column3: There is a place in Hell called Malebolge, Wholly of stone and of an iron colour, As is the circle that around it turns.

column2: Right in the middle of the field malign There yawns a well exceeding wide and deep, Of which its place the structure will recount.
column3: Right in the middle of the field malign There yawns a well exceeding wide and deep, Of which its place the structure will recount.

column2: Round, then, is that enclosure which remains Between the well and foot of the high, hard bank, And has distinct in valleys ten its bottom.
column3: Round, then, is that enclosure which remains Between the well and foot of the high, hard bank, And has distinct in valleys ten its bottom.

column2: As where for the protection of the walls Many and many moats surround the castles, The part in which they are a figure forms,
column3: As where for the protection of the walls Many and many moats surround the castles, The part in which they are a figure forms,

column2: Just such an image those presented there; And as about such strongholds from their gates Unto the outer bank are little bridges,
column3: Just such an image those presented there; And as about such strongholds from their gates Unto the outer bank are little bridges,

column2: So from the precipice's base did crags Project, which intersected dikes and moats, Unto the well that truncates and collects them.
column3: So from the precipice's base did crags Project, which intersected dikes and moats, Unto the well that truncates and collects them.

column2: Within this place, down shaken from the back Of Geryon, we found us; and the Poet Held to the left, and I moved on behind.
column3: Within this place, down shaken from the back Of Geryon, we found us; and the Poet Held to the left, and I moved on behind.

column2: Upon my right hand I beheld new anguish, New torments, and new wielders of the lash, Wherewith the foremost Bolgia was replete.
column3: Upon my right hand I beheld new anguish, New torments, and new wielders of the lash, Wherewith the foremost Bolgia was replete.

column2: Down at the bottom were the sinners naked; This side the middle came they facing us, Beyond it, with us, but with greater steps;
column3: Down at the bottom were the sinners naked; This side the middle came they facing us, Beyond it, with us, but with greater steps;

column2: Even as the Romans, for the mighty host, The year of Jubilee, upon the bridge, Have chosen a mode to pass the people over;
column3: Even as the romans, for the mighty host, The year of Jubilee, upon the bridge, Have chosen a mode to pass the people over;

column2: For all upon one side towards the Castle Their faces have, and go unto St. Peter's; On the other side they go towards the Mountain.
column3: For all upon one side towards the Castle Their faces have, and go unto saint Peter's; On the other side they go towards the Mountain.

column2: This side and that, along the livid stone Beheld I horned demons with great scourges, Who cruelly were beating them behind.
column3: This side and that, along the livid stone Beheld I horned demons with great scourges, Who cruelly were beating them behind.

column2: Ah me! how they did make them lift their legs At the first blows! and sooth not any one The second waited for, nor for the third.
column3: Ah me! how they did make them lift their legs At the first blows! and sooth not any one The second waited for, nor for the third.

column2: While I was going on, mine eyes by one Encountered were; and straight I said: "Already With sight of this one I am not unfed."
column3: While I was going on, mine eyes by one Encountered were; and straight I said: "Already With sight of this one I am not unfed."

column2: Therefore I stayed my feet to make him out, And with me the sweet Guide came to a stand, And to my going somewhat back assented;
column3: Therefore I stayed my feet to make him out, And with me the sweet Guide came to a stand, And to my going somewhat back assented;

column2: And he, the scourged one, thought to hide himself, Lowering his face, but little it availed him; For said I: "Thou that castest down thine eyes,
column3: And he, the scourged one, thought to hide himself, Lowering his face, but little it availed him; For said I: "Thou that castest down thine eyes,

column2: If false are not the features which thou bearest, Thou art Venedico Caccianimico; But what doth bring thee to such pungent sauces?"
column3: If false are not the features which thou bearest, Thou art Venedico Caccianimico; But what doth bring thee to such pungent sauces?"

column2: And he to me: "Unwillingly I tell it; But forces me thine utterance distinct, Which makes me recollect the ancient world.
column3: And he to me: "Unwillingly I tell it; But forces me thine utterance distinct, Which makes me recollect the ancient world.

column2: I was the one who the fair Ghisola Induced to grant the wishes of the Marquis, Howe'er the shameless story may be told.
column3: I was the one who the fair Ghisola Induced to grant the wishes of the Marquis, Howe'er the shameless story may be told.

column2: Not the sole Bolognese am I who weeps here; Nay, rather is this place so full of them, That not so many tongues to-day are taught
column3: Not the sole Bolognese am I who weeps here; Nay, rather is this place so full of them, That not so many tongues to day are taught

column2: 'Twixt Reno and Savena to say 'sipa;' And if thereof thou wishest pledge or proof, Bring to thy mind our avaricious heart."
column3: 'Twixt Reno and Savena to say 's i p a;' And if thereof thou wishest pledge or proof, Bring to thy mind our avaricious heart."

column2: While speaking in this manner, with his scourge A demon smote him, and said: "Get thee gone Pander, there are no women here for coin."
column3: While speaking in this manner, with his scourge A demon smote him, and said: "Get thee gone Pander, there are no women here for coin."

column2: I joined myself again unto mine Escort; Thereafterward with footsteps few we came To where a crag projected from the bank.
column3: I joined myself again unto mine Escort; Thereafterward with footsteps few we came To where a crag projected from the bank.

column2: This very easily did we ascend, And turning to the right along its ridge, From those eternal circles we departed.
column3: This very easily did we ascend, And turning to the right along its ridge, From those eternal circles we departed.

column2: When we were there, where it is hollowed out Beneath, to give a passage to the scourged, The Guide said: "Wait, and see that on thee strike
column3: When we were there, where it is hollowed out Beneath, to give a passage to the scourged, The Guide said: "Wait, and see that on thee strike

column2: The vision of those others evil-born, Of whom thou hast not yet beheld the faces, Because together with us they have gone."
column3: The vision of those others evil born, Of whom thou hast not yet beheld the faces, Because together with us they have gone."

column2: From the old bridge we looked upon the train Which tow'rds us came upon the other border, And which the scourges in like manner smite.
column3: From the old bridge we looked upon the train Which tow'rds us came upon the other border, And which the scourges in like manner smite.

column2: And the good Master, without my inquiring, Said to me: "See that tall one who is coming, And for his pain seems not to shed a tear;
column3: And the good Master, without my inquiring, Said to me: "See that tall one who is coming, And for his pain seems not to shed a tear;

column2: Still what a royal aspect he retains! That Jason is, who by his heart and cunning The Colchians of the Ram made destitute.
column3: Still what a royal aspect he retains! That Jason is, who by his heart and cunning The Colchians of the Ram made destitute.

column2: He by the isle of Lemnos passed along After the daring women pitiless Had unto death devoted all their males.
column3: He by the isle of Lemnos passed along After the daring women pitiless Had unto death devoted all their males.

column2: There with his tokens and with ornate words Did he deceive Hypsipyle, the maiden Who first, herself, had all the rest deceived.
column3: There with his tokens and with ornate words Did he deceive Hypsipyle, the maiden Who first, herself, had all the rest deceived.

column2: There did he leave her pregnant and forlorn; Such sin unto such punishment condemns him, And also for Medea is vengeance done.
column3: There did he leave her pregnant and forlorn; Such sin unto such punishment condemns him, And also for Medea is vengeance done.

column2: With him go those who in such wise deceive; And this sufficient be of the first valley To know, and those that in its jaws it holds."
column3: With him go those who in such wise deceive; And this sufficient be of the first valley To know, and those that in its jaws it holds."

column2: We were already where the narrow path Crosses athwart the second dike, and forms Of that a buttress for another arch.
column3: We were already where the narrow path Crosses athwart the second dike, and forms Of that a buttress for another arch.

column2: Thence we heard people, who are making moan In the next Bolgia, snorting with their muzzles, And with their palms beating upon themselves
column3: Thence we heard people, who are making moan In the next Bolgia, snorting with their muzzles, And with their palms beating upon themselves

column2: The margins were incrusted with a mould By exhalation from below, that sticks there, And with the eyes and nostrils wages war.
column3: The margins were incrusted with a mould By exhalation from below, that sticks there, And with the eyes and nostrils wages war.

column2: The bottom is so deep, no place suffices To give us sight of it, without ascending The arch's back, where most the crag impends.
column3: The bottom is so deep, no place suffices To give us sight of it, without ascending The arch's back, where most the crag impends.

column2: Thither we came, and thence down in the moat I saw a people smothered in a filth That out of human privies seemed to flow;
column3: Thither we came, and thence down in the moat I saw a people smothered in a filth That out of human privies seemed to flow;

column2: And whilst below there with mine eye I search, I saw one with his head so foul with ordure, It was not clear if he were clerk or layman.
column3: And whilst below there with mine eye I search, I saw one with his head so foul with ordure, It was not clear if he were clerk or layman.

column2: He screamed to me: "Wherefore art thou so eager To look at me more than the other foul ones?" And I to him: "Because, if I remember,
column3: He screamed to me: "Wherefore art thou so eager To look at me more than the other foul ones?" And I to him: "Because, if I remember,

column2: I have already seen thee with dry hair, And thou'rt Alessio Interminei of Lucca; Therefore I eye thee more than all the others."
column3: I have already seen thee with dry hair, And thou'rt Alessio Interminei of Lucca; Therefore I eye thee more than all the others."

column2: And he thereon, belabouring his pumpkin: "The flatteries have submerged me here below, Wherewith my tongue was never surfeited."
column3: And he thereon, belabouring his pumpkin: "The flatteries have submerged me here below, Wherewith my tongue was never surfeited."

column2: Then said to me the Guide: "See that thou thrust Thy visage somewhat farther in advance, That with thine eyes thou well the face attain
column3: Then said to me the Guide: "See that thou thrust Thy visage somewhat farther in advance, That with thine eyes thou well the face attain

column2: Of that uncleanly and dishevelled drab, Who there doth scratch herself with filthy nails, And crouches now, and now on foot is standing.
column3: Of that uncleanly and dishevelled drab, Who there doth scratch herself with filthy nails, And crouches now, and now on foot is standing.

column2: Thais the harlot is it, who replied Unto her paramour, when he said, 'Have I Great gratitude from thee?'--'Nay, marvellous;'
column3: Thais the harlot is it, who replied Unto her paramour, when he said, 'Have I Great gratitude from thee?'--'Nay, marvellous;'

column2: And herewith let our sight be satisfied."
column3: And herewith let our sight be satisfied."

column2: Inferno: Canto XIX
column3: Inferno: Canto nineteen

column2: O Simon Magus, O forlorn disciples, Ye who the things of God, which ought to be The brides of holiness, rapaciously
column3: O Simon Magus, O forlorn disciples, Ye who the things of God, which ought to be The brides of holiness, rapaciously

column2: For silver and for gold do prostitute, Now it behoves for you the trumpet sound, Because in this third Bolgia ye abide.
column3: For silver and for gold do prostitute, Now it behoves for you the trumpet sound, Because in this third Bolgia ye abide.

column2: We had already on the following tomb Ascended to that portion of the crag Which o'er the middle of the moat hangs plumb.
column3: We had already on the following tomb Ascended to that portion of the crag Which o'er the middle of the moat hangs plumb.

column2: Wisdom supreme, O how great art thou showest In heaven, in earth, and in the evil world, And with what justice doth thy power distribute!
column3: Wisdom supreme, O how great art thou showest In heaven, in earth, and in the evil world, And with what justice doth thy power distribute!

column2: I saw upon the sides and on the bottom The livid stone with perforations filled, All of one size, and every one was round.
column3: I saw upon the sides and on the bottom The livid stone with perforations filled, All of one size, and every one was round.

column2: To me less ample seemed they not, nor greater Than those that in my beautiful Saint John Are fashioned for the place of the baptisers,
column3: To me less ample seemed they not, nor greater Than those that in my beautiful Saint john Are fashioned for the place of the baptisers,

column2: And one of which, not many years ago, I broke for some one, who was drowning in it; Be this a seal all men to undeceive.
column3: And one of which, not many years ago, I broke for some one, who was drowning in it; Be this a seal all men to undeceive.

column2: Out of the mouth of each one there protruded The feet of a transgressor, and the legs Up to the calf, the rest within remained.
column3: Out of the mouth of each one there protruded The feet of a transgressor, and the legs Up to the calf, the rest within remained.

column2: In all of them the soles were both on fire; Wherefore the joints so violently quivered, They would have snapped asunder withes and bands.
column3: In all of them the soles were both on fire; Wherefore the joints so violently quivered, They would have snapped asunder withes and bands.

column2: Even as the flame of unctuous things is wont To move upon the outer surface only, So likewise was it there from heel to point.
column3: Even as the flame of unctuous things is wont To move upon the outer surface only, So likewise was it there from heel to point.

column2: Master, who is that one who writhes himself, More than his other comrades quivering, I said, "and whom a redder flame is sucking?"
column3: Master, who is that one who writhes himself, More than his other comrades quivering, I said, "and whom a redder flame is sucking?"

column2: And he to me: "If thou wilt have me bear thee Down there along that bank which lowest lies, From him thou'lt know his errors and himself."
column3: And he to me: "If thou wilt have me bear thee Down there along that bank which lowest lies, From him thou'lt know his errors and himself."

column2: And I: "What pleases thee, to me is pleasing; Thou art my Lord, and knowest that I depart not From thy desire, and knowest what is not spoken."
column3: And I: "What pleases thee, to me is pleasing; Thou art my Lord, and knowest that I depart not From thy desire, and knowest what is not spoken."

column2: Straightway upon the fourth dike we arrived; We turned, and on the left-hand side descended Down to the bottom full of holes and narrow.
column3: Straightway upon the fourth dike we arrived; We turned, and on the left hand side descended Down to the bottom full of holes and narrow.

column2: And the good Master yet from off his haunch Deposed me not, till to the hole he brought me Of him who so lamented with his shanks.
column3: And the good Master yet from off his haunch Deposed me not, till to the hole he brought me Of him who so lamented with his shanks.

column2: Whoe'er thou art, that standest upside down, O doleful soul, implanted like a stake, To say began I, "if thou canst, speak out."
column3: Whoe'er thou art, that standest upside down, O doleful soul, implanted like a stake, To say began I, "if thou canst, speak out."

column2: I stood even as the friar who is confessing The false assassin, who, when he is fixed, Recalls him, so that death may be delayed.
column3: I stood even as the friar who is confessing The false assassin, who, when he is fixed, Recalls him, so that death may be delayed.

column2: And he cried out: "Dost thou stand there already, Dost thou stand there already, Boniface? By many years the record lied to me.
column3: And he cried out: "Dost thou stand there already, Dost thou stand there already, Boniface? By many years the record lied to me.

column2: Art thou so early satiate with that wealth, For which thou didst not fear to take by fraud The beautiful Lady, and then work her woe?"
column3: Art thou so early satiate with that wealth, For which thou didst not fear to take by fraud The beautiful Lady, and then work her woe?"

column2: Such I became, as people are who stand, Not comprehending what is answered them, As if bemocked, and know not how to answer.
column3: Such I became, as people are who stand, Not comprehending what is answered them, As if bemocked, and know not how to answer.

column2: Then said Virgilius: "Say to him straightway, 'I am not he, I am not he thou thinkest.'" And I replied as was imposed on me.
column3: Then said Virgilius: "Say to him straightway, 'I am not he, I am not he thou thinkest.'" And I replied as was imposed on me.

column2: Whereat the spirit writhed with both his feet, Then, sighing, with a voice of lamentation Said to me: "Then what wantest thou of me?
column3: Whereat the spirit writhed with both his feet, Then, sighing, with a voice of lamentation Said to me: "Then what wantest thou of me?

column2: If who I am thou carest so much to know, That thou on that account hast crossed the bank, Know that I vested was with the great mantle;
column3: If who I am thou carest so much to know, That thou on that account hast crossed the bank, Know that I vested was with the great mantle;

column2: And truly was I son of the She-bear, So eager to advance the cubs, that wealth Above, and here myself, I pocketed.
column3: And truly was I son of the She bear, So eager to advance the cubs, that wealth Above, and here myself, I pocketed.

column2: Beneath my head the others are dragged down Who have preceded me in simony, Flattened along the fissure of the rock.
column3: Beneath my head the others are dragged down Who have preceded me in simony, Flattened along the fissure of the rock.

column2: Below there I shall likewise fall, whenever That one shall come who I believed thou wast, What time the sudden question I proposed.
column3: Below there I shall likewise fall, whenever That one shall come who I believed thou wast, What time the sudden question I proposed.

column2: But longer I my feet already toast, And here have been in this way upside down, Than he will planted stay with reddened feet;
column3: But longer I my feet already toast, And here have been in this way upside down, Than he will planted stay with reddened feet;

column2: For after him shall come of fouler deed From tow'rds the west a Pastor without law, Such as befits to cover him and me.
column3: For after him shall come of fouler deed From tow'rds the west a Pastor without law, Such as befits to cover him and me.

column2: New Jason will he be, of whom we read In Maccabees; and as his king was pliant, So he who governs France shall be to this one."
column3: New Jason will he be, of whom we read In Maccabees; and as his king was pliant, So he who governs France shall be to this one."

column2: I do not know if I were here too bold, That him I answered only in this metre: "I pray thee tell me now how great a treasure
column3: I do not know if I were here too bold, That him I answered only in this metre: "I pray thee tell me now how great a treasure

column2: Our Lord demanded of Saint Peter first, Before he put the keys into his keeping? Truly he nothing asked but 'Follow me.'
column3: Our Lord demanded of Saint peter first, Before he put the keys into his keeping? Truly he nothing asked but 'Follow me.'

column2: Nor Peter nor the rest asked of Matthias Silver or gold, when he by lot was chosen Unto the place the guilty soul had lost.
column3: Nor peter nor the rest asked of Matthias Silver or gold, when he by lot was chosen Unto the place the guilty soul had lost.

column2: Therefore stay here, for thou art justly punished, And keep safe guard o'er the ill-gotten money, Which caused thee to be valiant against Charles.
column3: Therefore stay here, for thou art justly punished, And keep safe guard o'er the ill gotten money, Which caused thee to be valiant against Charles.

column2: And were it not that still forbids it me The reverence for the keys superlative Thou hadst in keeping in the gladsome life,
column3: And were it not that still forbids it me The reverence for the keys superlative Thou hadst in keeping in the gladsome life,

column2: I would make use of words more grievous still; Because your avarice afflicts the world, Trampling the good and lifting the depraved.
column3: I would make use of words more grievous still; Because your avarice afflicts the world, Trampling the good and lifting the depraved.

column2: The Evangelist you Pastors had in mind, When she who sitteth upon many waters To fornicate with kings by him was seen;
column3: The Evangelist you Pastors had in mind, When she who sitteth upon many waters To fornicate with kings by him was seen;

column2: The same who with the seven heads was born, And power and strength from the ten horns received, So long as virtue to her spouse was pleasing.
column3: The same who with the seven heads was born, And power and strength from the ten horns received, So long as virtue to her spouse was pleasing.

column2: Ye have made yourselves a god of gold and silver; And from the idolater how differ ye, Save that he one, and ye a hundred worship?
column3: Ye have made yourselves a god of gold and silver; And from the idolater how differ ye, Save that he one, and ye a hundred worship?

column2: Ah, Constantine! of how much ill was mother, Not thy conversion, but that marriage dower Which the first wealthy Father took from thee!"
column3: Ah, Constantine! of how much ill was mother, Not thy conversion, but that marriage dower Which the first wealthy Father took from thee!"

column2: And while I sang to him such notes as these, Either that anger or that conscience stung him, He struggled violently with both his feet.
column3: And while I sang to him such notes as these, Either that anger or that conscience stung him, He struggled violently with both his feet.

column2: I think in sooth that it my Leader pleased, With such contented lip he listened ever Unto the sound of the true words expressed.
column3: I think in sooth that it my Leader pleased, With such contented lip he listened ever Unto the sound of the true words expressed.

column2: Therefore with both his arms he took me up, And when he had me all upon his breast, Remounted by the way where he descended.
column3: Therefore with both his arms he took me up, And when he had me all upon his breast, Remounted by the way where he descended.

column2: Nor did he tire to have me clasped to him; But bore me to the summit of the arch Which from the fourth dike to the fifth is passage.
column3: Nor did he tire to have me clasped to him; But bore me to the summit of the arch Which from the fourth dike to the fifth is passage.

column2: There tenderly he laid his burden down, Tenderly on the crag uneven and steep, That would have been hard passage for the goats:
column3: There tenderly he laid his burden down, Tenderly on the crag uneven and steep, That would have been hard passage for the goats:

column2: Thence was unveiled to me another valley.
column3: Thence was unveiled to me another valley.

column2: Inferno: Canto XX
column3: Inferno: Canto x x

column2: Of a new pain behoves me to make verses And give material to the twentieth canto Of the first song, which is of the submerged.
column3: Of a new pain behoves me to make verses And give material to the twentieth canto Of the first song, which is of the submerged.

column2: I was already thoroughly disposed To peer down into the uncovered depth, Which bathed itself with tears of agony;
column3: I was already thoroughly disposed To peer down into the uncovered depth, Which bathed itself with tears of agony;

column2: And people saw I through the circular valley, Silent and weeping, coming at the pace Which in this world the Litanies assume.
column3: And people saw I through the circular valley, Silent and weeping, coming at the pace Which in this world the Litanies assume.

column2: As lower down my sight descended on them, Wondrously each one seemed to be distorted From chin to the beginning of the chest;
column3: As lower down my sight descended on them, Wondrously each one seemed to be distorted From chin to the beginning of the chest;

column2: For tow'rds the reins the countenance was turned, And backward it behoved them to advance, As to look forward had been taken from them.
column3: For tow'rds the reins the countenance was turned, And backward it behoved them to advance, As to look forward had been taken from them.

column2: Perchance indeed by violence of palsy Some one has been thus wholly turned awry; But I ne'er saw it, nor believe it can be.
column3: Perchance indeed by violence of palsy Some one has been thus wholly turned awry; But I ne'er saw it, nor believe it can be.

column2: As God may let thee, Reader, gather fruit From this thy reading, think now for thyself How I could ever keep my face unmoistened,
column3: As God may let thee, Reader, gather fruit From this thy reading, think now for thyself How I could ever keep my face unmoistened,

column2: When our own image near me I beheld Distorted so, the weeping of the eyes Along the fissure bathed the hinder parts.
column3: When our own image near me I beheld Distorted so, the weeping of the eyes Along the fissure bathed the hinder parts.

column2: Truly I wept, leaning upon a peak Of the hard crag, so that my Escort said To me: "Art thou, too, of the other fools?
column3: Truly I wept, leaning upon a peak Of the hard crag, so that my Escort said To me: "Art thou, too, of the other fools?

column2: Here pity lives when it is wholly dead; Who is a greater reprobate than he Who feels compassion at the doom divine?
column3: Here pity lives when it is wholly dead; Who is a greater reprobate than he Who feels compassion at the doom divine?

column2: Lift up, lift up thy head, and see for whom Opened the earth before the Thebans' eyes; Wherefore they all cried: 'Whither rushest thou,
column3: Lift up, lift up thy head, and see for whom Opened the earth before the Thebans' eyes; Wherefore they all cried: 'Whither rushest thou,

column2: Amphiaraus?
column3: Amphiaraus?

column2: Why dost leave the war?' And downward ceased he not to fall amain As far as Minos, who lays hold on all.
column3: Why dost leave the war?' And downward ceased he not to fall amain As far as Minos, who lays hold on all.

column2: See, he has made a bosom of his shoulders! Because he wished to see too far before him Behind he looks, and backward goes his way:
column3: See, he has made a bosom of his shoulders! Because he wished to see too far before him Behind he looks, and backward goes his way:

column2: Behold Tiresias, who his semblance changed, When from a male a female he became, His members being all of them transformed;
column3: Behold Tiresias, who his semblance changed, When from a male a female he became, His members being all of them transformed;

column2: And afterwards was forced to strike once more The two entangled serpents with his rod, Ere he could have again his manly plumes.
column3: And afterwards was forced to strike once more The two entangled serpents with his rod, Ere he could have again his manly plumes.

column2: That Aruns is, who backs the other's belly, Who in the hills of Luni, there where grubs The Carrarese who houses underneath,
column3: That Aruns is, who backs the other's belly, Who in the hills of Luni, there where grubs The Carrarese who houses underneath,

column2: Among the marbles white a cavern had For his abode; whence to behold the stars And sea, the view was not cut off from him.
column3: Among the marbles white a cavern had For his abode; whence to behold the stars And sea, the view was not cut off from him.

column2: And she there, who is covering up her breasts, Which thou beholdest not, with loosened tresses, And on that side has all the hairy skin,
column3: And she there, who is covering up her breasts, Which thou beholdest not, with loosened tresses, And on that side has all the hairy skin,

column2: Was Manto, who made quest through many lands, Afterwards tarried there where I was born; Whereof I would thou list to me a little.
column3: Was Manto, who made quest through many lands, Afterwards tarried there where I was born; Whereof I would thou list to me a little.

column2: After her father had from life departed, And the city of Bacchus had become enslaved, She a long season wandered through the world.
column3: After her father had from life departed, And the city of Bacchus had become enslaved, She a long season wandered through the world.

column2: Above in beauteous Italy lies a lake At the Alp's foot that shuts in Germany Over Tyrol, and has the name Benaco.
column3: Above in beauteous Italy lies a lake At the Alp's foot that shuts in Germany Over Tyrol, and has the name Benaco.

column2: By a thousand springs, I think, and more, is bathed, 'Twixt Garda and Val Camonica, Pennino, With water that grows stagnant in that lake.
column3: By a thousand springs, I think, and more, is bathed, 'Twixt Garda and Val Camonica, Pennino, With water that grows stagnant in that lake.

column2: Midway a place is where the Trentine Pastor, And he of Brescia, and the Veronese Might give his blessing, if he passed that way.
column3: Midway a place is where the Trentine Pastor, And he of Brescia, and the Veronese Might give his blessing, if he passed that way.

column2: Sitteth Peschiera, fortress fair and strong, To front the Brescians and the Bergamasks, Where round about the bank descendeth lowest.
column3: Sitteth Peschiera, fortress fair and strong, To front the Brescians and the Bergamasks, Where round about the bank descendeth lowest.

column2: There of necessity must fall whatever In bosom of Benaco cannot stay, And grows a river down through verdant pastures.
column3: There of necessity must fall whatever In bosom of Benaco cannot stay, And grows a river down through verdant pastures.

column2: Soon as the water doth begin to run, No more Benaco is it called, but Mincio, Far as Governo, where it falls in Po.
column3: Soon as the water doth begin to run, No more Benaco is it called, but Mincio, Far as Governo, where it falls in Po.

column2: Not far it runs before it finds a plain In which it spreads itself, and makes it marshy, And oft 'tis wont in summer to be sickly.
column3: Not far it runs before it finds a plain In which it spreads itself, and makes it marshy, And oft 'tis wont in summer to be sickly.

column2: Passing that way the virgin pitiless Land in the middle of the fen descried, Untilled and naked of inhabitants;
column3: Passing that way the virgin pitiless Land in the middle of the fen descried, Untilled and naked of inhabitants;

column2: There to escape all human intercourse, She with her servants stayed, her arts to practise And lived, and left her empty body there.
column3: There to escape all human intercourse, She with her servants stayed, her arts to practise And lived, and left her empty body there.

column2: The men, thereafter, who were scattered round, Collected in that place, which was made strong By the lagoon it had on every side;
column3: The men, thereafter, who were scattered round, Collected in that place, which was made strong By the lagoon it had on every side;

column2: They built their city over those dead bones, And, after her who first the place selected, Mantua named it, without other omen.
column3: They built their city over those dead bones, And, after her who first the place selected, Mantua named it, without other omen.

column2: Its people once within more crowded were, Ere the stupidity of Casalodi From Pinamonte had received deceit.
column3: Its people once within more crowded were, Ere the stupidity of Casalodi From Pinamonte had received deceit.

column2: Therefore I caution thee, if e'er thou hearest Originate my city otherwise, No falsehood may the verity defraud."
column3: Therefore I caution thee, if e'er thou hearest Originate my city otherwise, No falsehood may the verity defraud."

column2: And I: "My Master, thy discourses are To me so certain, and so take my faith, That unto me the rest would be spent coals.
column3: And I: "My Master, thy discourses are To me so certain, and so take my faith, That unto me the rest would be spent coals.

column2: But tell me of the people who are passing, If any one note-worthy thou beholdest, For only unto that my mind reverts."
column3: But tell me of the people who are passing, If any one note worthy thou beholdest, For only unto that my mind reverts."

column2: Then said he to me: "He who from the cheek Thrusts out his beard upon his swarthy shoulders Was, at the time when Greece was void of males,
column3: Then said he to me: "He who from the cheek Thrusts out his beard upon his swarthy shoulders Was, at the time when Greece was void of males,

column2: So that there scarce remained one in the cradle, An augur, and with Calchas gave the moment, In Aulis, when to sever the first cable.
column3: So that there scarce remained one in the cradle, An augur, and with Calchas gave the moment, In Aulis, when to sever the first cable.

column2: Eryphylus his name was, and so sings My lofty Tragedy in some part or other; That knowest thou well, who knowest the whole of it.
column3: Eryphylus his name was, and so sings My lofty Tragedy in some part or other; That knowest thou well, who knowest the whole of it.

column2: The next, who is so slender in the flanks, Was Michael Scott, who of a verity Of magical illusions knew the game.
column3: The next, who is so slender in the flanks, Was Michael Scott, who of a verity Of magical illusions knew the game.

column2: Behold Guido Bonatti, behold Asdente, Who now unto his leather and his thread Would fain have stuck, but he too late repents.
column3: Behold Guido Bonatti, behold Asdente, Who now unto his leather and his thread Would fain have stuck, but he too late repents.

column2: Behold the wretched ones, who left the needle, The spool and rock, and made them fortune-tellers; They wrought their magic spells with herb and image.
column3: Behold the wretched ones, who left the needle, The spool and rock, and made them fortune tellers; They wrought their magic spells with herb and image.

column2: But come now, for already holds the confines Of both the hemispheres, and under Seville Touches the ocean-wave, Cain and the thorns,
column3: But come now, for already holds the confines Of both the hemispheres, and under Seville Touches the ocean wave, Cain and the thorns,

column2: And yesternight the moon was round already; Thou shouldst remember well it did not harm thee From time to time within the forest deep."
column3: And yesternight the moon was round already; Thou shouldst remember well it did not harm thee From time to time within the forest deep."

column2: Thus spake he to me, and we walked the while.
column3: Thus spake he to me, and we walked the while.

column2: Inferno: Canto XXI
column3: Inferno: Canto twenty one

column2: From bridge to bridge thus, speaking other things Of which my Comedy cares not to sing, We came along, and held the summit, when
column3: From bridge to bridge thus, speaking other things Of which my Comedy cares not to sing, We came along, and held the summit, when

column2: We halted to behold another fissure Of Malebolge and other vain laments; And I beheld it marvellously dark.
column3: We halted to behold another fissure Of Malebolge and other vain laments; And I beheld it marvellously dark.

column2: As in the Arsenal of the Venetians Boils in the winter the tenacious pitch To smear their unsound vessels o'er again,
column3: As in the Arsenal of the Venetians Boils in the winter the tenacious pitch To smear their unsound vessels o'er again,
